﻿         Motivation Lab                                                                        NYU Psychology    Programs    Courses    Research    Faculty    People    Events    Contacts    [Internal]          Motivation Lab                                              Gollwitzer    Oettingen    Members    Address                         Motivation Lab     The Motivation Lab at NYU explores how conscious and non-conscious processes interact in influencing people’s thought, emotion, and behavior. Research has focused on fantasies, goals, and plans, and their role in self-regulating human functioning. We also consider contextual influences on self-regulatory processes. Research methods span from highly controlled lab experiments to field interventions applying the discovered principles to solve current real world problems. We use neuro-imaging to classic cognitive reaction time paradigms to observational, self-report, and field experimental techniques. As we focus on discovering content-free principles of how conscious and non-conscious processes regulate human thought, emotion, and behavior, our research can be tested and applied in all areas of psychology. For example, we publish in Journals of Social and Personality Psychology, Developmental Psychology, Clinical Psychology, Organizational Psychology, Educational Psychology, Consumer Psychology, as well as in Journals of Neuroscience and in Medical Journals.                  Updated

Motivation Lab                                                                                                           NYU Psychology     Programs     Courses     Research     Faculty     People     Events     Contacts     [Internal]             Motivation Lab                                                         Gollwitzer     Oettingen     Members     Address                                             Members      Alex Wesnousky                Research Interests:            Motivation and identity, especially in the  context of maladaptive or negative identity labels.       How do disease labels and diagnoses influence  regulatory thought and behavior, and how can they have both negative and  positive consequences.           E-Mail: aew323@nyu.edu            Ana Gantman             Research Interests:            Conscious/nonconscious goal switching       Feelings of agency and unconscious goal pursuit       The explanatory vacuum in nonconsious  goal-directed action           E-Mail: agantman@nyu.edu            Bryan Sim            Research Interests:                 How does competition affect the way we set and pursue our goals?       What makes us compete, and when do we do it?       How are we affected, psychologically and socially, by competing?           E-Mail : bryan.sim@nyu.edu           Christina Crosby            Research Interests:                 The gap that exists between behavioral intentions and actual behavior       The process of goal disengagement and how to keep people engaged to difficult, but important goals           E-Mail : christina.crosby@nyu.edu           Janet Ahn             Research Interests:            The projection of explicit and and implicit goals       The social consequences of projecting goals (either cooperative or competitive)           E-Mail: janet.ahn@nyu.edu                        Katherine Reilly Thorson             Research Interests:                Relationship between self-regulation and emotion       Influences of emotion and stress on behavior       Self-regulation and psychophysiology           E-Mail :  katherine.thorson@nyu.edu            John Sciarappo            Research Interests:                 How self-regulatory strategies and mental simulations impact the cognitive structure of goal-systems       Facilitating the productive regulation of agency/authorship/control inference       When and how early-life conflict gives rise to maladaptive automatic goal-pursuit later in life           E-Mail : john.sciarappo@nyu.edu                Yanitsa Toneva            Research Interests:                 The relationship between self-regulation and creative thinking       The different motivation factors that shape creative performance and achievement           E-Mail : yt841@nyu.edu         Research Assistant    Julie Youko Anne Cachia            Research Interests:                 How do cultural factors shape self-regulation?       What role does self-regulation play in interpersonal relationships?
